title: Open Data, Open Database: PostgreSQL
segmentation: Good afternoon, I'm going to talk to you this afternoon about open data and open databases.
I've got about 15 minutes plus questions, so this talk is going to be a little bit fast, but you're very welcome to speak to me afterwards.
I'm going to talk about two topics this afternoon.
First of all, we're going to talk about Postgre SQL, the database server, and then we're going to talk a little bit about the axle project, which is an EU funded project.
To enhance the Postgre SQL Server for Big Data is doing some other things as well, but that's one of the main things.
So my starting point really is to think about what open now.
This means with respect to open data and software and standards and my starting point for thinking about that is the story of two famous European scientists, Isaac Newton and Darwin.
Now both of those scientists produce quite exciting results.
I think you'll agree, but the reason they were able to produce those results was because they were working on a platform of open data.
So Newton produced his results becausw some very accurate astronomical results were shared with him.
Now it wasn't anybody in Britain that produced that data.
It was actually part of the forming culture of openness in Europe that allowed the results to be shared with Newton.
That allowed him to formulate his theory and the same with Darwin, the work of many biologists over a long period of time.
Categorizing the whole host of species in our world was the backdrop on which Darwin could work.
So so both of those scientists started with open data.
Look what they ended up with now.
The second point on that I'd have to observe with both Newton and Darwin is that in both cases, for about 20 years they did not share their results.
All their methods, and so the second point really is that it's perfectly human and natural to want to.
Use what other people give you, but not give it back.
OK, that's perfectly normal and natural, and if you're thinking that with your scientific results then you're just human like the rest of us.
OK, so the point is that you have to open up, but you have to believe that if you give back that you will receive some benefit from that in the end.

So taking those thoughts and applying that to open data and open source, I see that those things are in fact connected the principles by which we measure openness of data are the same things that we used to measure openness of standards and the openness of software.
Now I am involved with one particular oath.

And source software project and that's the Postgre SQL Database server and I can tell you that the all of the standards of open NIS that I had on the previous slide are met by the Postgre SQL project.

It's completely open, anybody can get involved, it's not owned by a single company and it's got a very broad and open license that allows many people to use that software in a variety of different ways.

And as a result of that openness, the Postgre SQL project has got a bug defect rate that's approximately 100 times better than a lot of commercial software projects and certainly amongst the highest even amongst open source software projects.
Obviously being completely free helps its adoption as you might expect.
So what is postgre SQL?
It's starts life as a relational database server, it's SQL compliant and we closely track the development of the SQL standard as well as other eye.
So an international standards we work to an annual release policy, so the software itself is growing and changing and innovating at a disturbing rate.
Not disturbing for us, but.
For some people.
So some people say, well, SQL yeah, that's boring relational database, that's boring.
What we really want is.
Object relational database.
So postgre SQL is that as well.
User defined functions.

User defined data types and some new things called extensions which allow you to wrap plugins to the database now so easy is that to use that Postgres is the leading open source platform for GIS through the post GIS Data Store.
But there's also other extensions that you can get.
We don't stop there because we actually support a range of post relational database features such as range types.
Which is going to be the basis for temporal database support.
We already natively support arrays and record types, so we're able to solve very complex structured data.
Are you say, well, that's still boring 'cause?
We really want to key value DBMS well.
We support that as well.
Is an extension called H Store that allows you to store basically any type of key with any type of value stored after it.
So we support the full key value store idea that you get in other databases are you say, but I've got some kind of textual data well we support.

XML and Jason data types natively in the database based on full UTF 8 support and a variety of other important things, not least of which is the ability to handle recursive queries, which allows us to do searches of graphs all fully indexible.
We also support fulltext indexing with user defined dictionaries used to find stemmers and a variety of language support.
All integrated within the database.

This so this is just the straight product out of the box, so all these different capabilities come about because the software has been developed over a long period of time and it's developed by a wide range of people for a variety of use cases.
So a lot of people.
I would say yeah, it's just a relational database and that's really where they're missing something.
It's actually a flexible data platform, but underlying that it's mature, robust and free.
People then say, yeah, right, that's so who's using it then?
Well, NASA, various other people, the Open University run their learning management system in production on Postgre SQL.
McAfee.
Use it to support their cloud infrastructure.
Cisco site every every interaction you make with Skype runs through Postgres supported by open Stack and Heroku are running 1.6 million databases.
Today on postgre SQL.
I bought an Apple soon after the news that Postgres is the default database installed on OS X.
And there's also versions for Windows, Red Hat, Aboon two etc.
Now, as you can see on the right hand side, I have to declare a self interest.
I work for an SMB company that is a platinum sponsor of Postgre SQL, so obviously that needs to be declared that you understand where I'm coming from.
Do we make any money from license is not a penny.
Do we make money?
Yes we do.
So what I'd like to.
Ask for your interest in next is a project called Axel which is advanced analytics for extremely large European databases.
Now there's a small but well formed consortium of database experts that are looking to do core database research into handling the big data problems of the EU.
That's basically advanced.

Performance research advanced hardware research into a number of different areas, but we're integrating that with visual analytics and also taking into account the concerns of security and privacy, which we know are paramounts these days in building big data stores.
So the reason I've come here today is not to really to tell you all about postcards, but to say that we're looking for partners.
That would be able to work with us.
In the shape of, you'll have big data.
You'll have clear use cases that we can execute and benchmark to see the improvements we can make in those areas and also a high benefit case for the those analysis.
So actually means something of value to the you if we can improve those cases for you.
Now we are starting the project in November 2012 and so over the next six months we're looking to select.
Some partners basically one to two partners is really what we're looking for.
We already have an excellent source of data in the Port of Eater data set, which is a complex medical systems company.
But in addition to that, we're using some industry standard benchmarks, but we would like to open the floor to a number of other interested parties.
So if you'd like to get in touch with myself.
Simon Riggs.
So that's my email address.

Very keen to hear from you and the types of data analysis and analysis that you're looking to perform on your European projects just to describe the various hats that I'm wearing on the CTO of 2nd Quadrant.
I'm also a major developer on the Postgre SQL project so if anybody thought that I was kind of sales guy or something like that then absolutely not.
I'm basically a.
Full time professional developer.
And I'm also the technical lead on the forthcoming axle project, so please get in touch.
Regrettably, I'm only here for today, and So what I'd like to do is draw your attention to some other interested parties on the axle project.
First of all, Adrian Crystal from the Barcelona Supercomputer Center is here for the full duration of the European data form.
And also, Stefano, who I'm sure many of you already knows Project Officer on many of the projects that being described here.
So if you can't get to talk to me in person, please get in touch by email or talk to one of those people mentioned and it's what I do.
So I actually like it.
If you came up to me and ask me difficult technical questions about anything I've described today.
So thank you so much.
Any experience you made on the usage?
Of course we SQL post GIS extension on a cloud texture.
Yeah, I mean it.
I think it's fair to say that databases run better on good hardware, and that doesn't tend to happen in the cloud, but.
Most guys does run quite well on fairly poor hardware as well.
Heroku, for example is completely cloud based, so when I said that 1.6 million databases, that's all on top of Amazon infrastructure, so there are platform as a service provider on top of.
On top of Amazon.
So yeah, it runs quite well in the cloud.
Latest release.
We've gone to a lot of trouble to implement power reductions, so as of now, with the greenest database available as well.
Several people suggested to go for note no experiment solution while tackling big data challenges.
For example, to use not post is but mother extension for another new skills, they just don't know what's your opinion about that and maybe you can point assuming benchmark.
They show that with the limits or postcard.
Obviously, you know.
I think it's fairly clear that I'm going to say postgre SQL is best.
Yeah, I mean so any other odd.
So I give after that.
This is kind of subject to that answer.
I mean basically the idea about post cases.
It's a flexible data platform now to a certain extent is always possible to invent an architecture that is directly optimal for a particular task and therefore.
Benchmarks exceed.
The things that Postgres would give you in any particular area and you can point it a number of specialists.
Data stores that do that, but the performance and the robustness that you get with with post codes offers basically kind of.
You know a dimension of choice.
For example, some of the databases that you pick don't offer very good robustness guarantees, whereas with Postgres there's actually an option that you can set at transaction level to turn.
Turn these performance guarantees on, which is the same thing is turning the robustness guarantee off.
By doing that, you can actually alter the performance that you get in your applications, so a lot of these architectural things are actually tradeoffs.
They're not necessarily just pure optimizations, and there's a lot of that going on when you look at the actual benchmarks of what process is capable of.
We're easily capable of doing a billion transactions a day, which that's just on a single node 32 CPU platform.
So sorry, that's a billion right transactions.
Now if you if you start looking at how many transactions you actually need to perform and do that on the back of an envelope, you'll see that that's actually enough.
Basically, from pretty much most of the things you want to do, OK, it's not enough for Facebook.
That it won't be enough for certain Google applications, but what we're really trying to hit is we're trying to support 99.9% of the world's data.
And associated applications, and by my observation, we do that.
So that was a long answer.
Sorry for that.

Similar to the question certified for Microsoft Postgres and semantic databases and Sparkle, is there any capacity or interest in my post rest to create a solution to semantic database is very emotional and the reason for coming here today is not to tell you it's perfect and it does everything.
Clearly I'm telling you about the actual project that we're doing, a lot of stuff that it doesn't do yet.
Sparkle is a great example of something that I have a particular interest in myself.
And I don't see any reason why fitting spark Sparkle parser to the front of the database would be something that we wouldn't want.
It seems like something that we really, really want.

Name from the relational world producing, you know something open source, first part would be really cool and Oracle has some bits, but yeah I mean I'm just kind of like looking at you and you're looking at me.
And so you know I'd go back to the the openness of postcards you know there's not a kind of triumvirate of people sitting there moodily deciding what to put into it.
Next is basically researchers solving problems, bringing new ideas to the table, and the community is completely open.
So you can just bring that along and and say you know I'm looking at implementing this type of data.
How would I go about it?
Now, of course you know half the room will say no, you know, but that's the way of life, isn't it?
So.
Having fun.
Your statement sounded like one of the things you will pursue in this research project will be support for sparkle or no.
I mean, obviously the road map I can think of extends many years ahead and covers a range of things.
So what we've done here is is pick up a set of connected features and there's interactions you know, for example, the advanced hardware analysis.
But that's being performed on the project is related to post grades, but it's not.
You know, the whole project isn't all going into postcards.
There's this sort of research in various areas as well.
So, for example, the University of Louisiana is produces visual analytics system called Orange, and they're looking to integrate Orange with Postgre SQL as part of this project.
So there's various areas here.
But but I can.
I can think of much more than that, so but you can't do it all at once.
Just the continuation of the discussion, and it's still discussion, right?
So what is the approach?
People around Postgres take?
Is it like extending with special data type which will support their RDF and then on top of it some kind of a query language which you can use to query the RDF data?
Or because obviously obviously for different data model right?
So they data management side?
I mean you would have a mismatch it right?
So I mean what was the discussion?
What is the state of the discussion?
Or what is the kind of mainstream thinking about?
Well, I mean the.
The thought it really is that postgre SQL is a flexible data platform and it's providing a whole set of services.
It's almost like a kind of data operating system that will allow you to implement your data type and then a set of services around that.
So currently you know the historical way of doing anything was do it in SQL.
Now I think everybody in the whole world including us.

Realize that that's not the only future, and that really, really means it's not the only language that we need to support, but in terms of developing a full RDF solution to your needs, I would welcome somebody to join the project and start saying we can do RDF this way.
We're certainly not restricted in our thinking, just in terms of the flexibility.
We offer in the service side functional languages.
We support 16 different server side languages so you can write functions in Perl, Python, Java, PPG SQL and host of others.
I think I mentioned PLR as well and then interfaces into the database.
We support all the normal interfaces, so there's a whole range of different ways of extending the system, so it's this idea of it being a sort of rich data platform.
It might not do exactly what you want, but you can extend it to do so, and then we, you know the main project would happily receive any extensions that people have made so.
